posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

I haven't ridden either bike so I can't say if it's the case for these bikes, but bikes designed to a low price point often focus more on the spec sheet than the actual riding characteristics of the bike. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26183506
Apart from 21/18” wheels it would require custom suspension parts and possibly a new swingarm. The design of the ftr’s swingarm looks nice but seems restrictive. This means you would have to change the mounting point of the shock as well.
An adventure bike’s suspension should ideally travel as vertically as possible, following the swingarm’s vector, instead of converting force sideways.
The ftr’s side-mounted shock is also an issue. Extending the shock and the nature of adventure riding will put excessive torsional stress on the current set-up.
If I were designing it from the ground up I would have a stiffer aluminium swingarm with dog-bone linkage suspension mounted to the centre of the frame.

>>26182905
I never rode while I was there but lived there for three years. The road signs are all in English (thank you MacArthur-sama) and the drivers are extremely concious of other road traffic and maybe a little too cautious to our wreckless sensibilities, you'll probably have to adjust your habits to expecting everyone to be overly generous about right of way at intersections and merging. Other than that, they're generally quite safe drivers around bikes because they're everywhere. Mail? Comes on a Supercub. Order a pizza? Supercub with a Dominoes box on the back. Ubereats? Supercub with a rider dressed as Tanjiro from Demon Slayer. The 2,000 shipyard workers flocking to and from work? Supercubs wearing their matching shipyard safety vests and chainsmoking while riding.
The main roads are impeccably maintained but the countryside can get a bit rough, lots of extremely narrow roads and unforseen hairpins, but they usually have a convex (or concave, dunno, failed physics) mirror at the corners so you can see who's coming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Has anyone bought a bigger motorcycle then realized they missed shifting? The usable powerband in any given gear is too wide, and the only reason to shift is launching or to get in a cruising gear. You never have to be in any particular gear. You can feather from a stop in 3rd, or keep up with surface traffic in first. A stop light launch is just first into second and managing the throttle to prevent a wheelie instead of going WOT. There's none of that sequential shifting when you launch because there's literally no other way to get up to speed like in a smaller bike, or having to shift to match traffic conditions because the bike will only pull in a certain gear at a certain speed.

>What purpose does having a random hole in the block have again?
Depending on your cars optionz it could have come with an external oil cooler. That port in the block is what feeds it. You can install the external cooler and alt bracket that goes with it to avoid having to ever change that dumb gasket again.

Luckily I don't need to mess with that bullshit. The ms45.1 dme doesn't have an auto or manual variant, it does both. It's all in the vehicle order, I just need to recode the vehicle order to remove the auto trans then update the cas, light module, dsc and clusters coding. Then use inpa to uncheck the auto option the dme under digital values, on the next key on it will check the vehicle order and realize that's there's no auto trans and default to manual.

For the people who haven't driven the other stages prior.
The rest of those stages are, with two exceptions, also some of the tougher gravel stages RBR has to offer. We'd ran a tarmac version of one of the Swiss stages, so you'd know what lack of margins of error you'd expect. The Diepflingen stages are that with a factor of ten.
I'd also recommend at least having a practice run on the Carvalho de Rei stages, those are stages with very nice flow, but with some brutal sectors where it is all too easy to crash off course.
This is one of the rallies you should count your lucky stars that it is on Reduced damage mode now, because you are going to need it for these stages.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26170899
Yeah, the final sector of Carvalho del Rei reverse is one of the most brutal gravel sections in RBR in my opinion. It's mostly due to the usual direction and sprint version being uphill, which is already tricky with a few nasty bumps, but it is only on the reverse stage you realize how steep that section really is. And having to brake hard downhill at full speed rarely ends well in RBR. It makes that downhill section very deceptive and treacherous even when aware how tricky it is. It's definitely one of the sections where you need to exercise utmost caution at every single bit, and it really doesn't let up until the finish line.
It's normal in most rallies to see most of the field either DNFing or racking up multiple CFHs on that stage whenever that stage is ran in it.

>>26173499
This
The newest racing game out right now is Unbound and it's literally a reskin of a reskin of a reskin of a game from 2014 which is just Burnout Paradise in the Battlefield 3 engine.
Once your PC runs all the games you enjoy playing you don't have to upgrade for years, there's no proprietary disk format or architecture change preventing you from playing the games you bought last gen.
If components do fail you can replace them. My OG Xbox is dead from old capacitors. My PSP's batteries have bulged. Vita needs to be cracked just to get on the internet. All my childhood pokeymans have been lost to the ether thanks to dead cmos batteries.
But on the PC I have access to literally every game on every platform ever conceived since the dawn of the computing age, direct access to all files and godlike control over the quality of my experience. There really is no comparison. If you really truly appreciate the vidya a PC is the only choice and the slightly higher buy in cost is completely justified by how infinitely useful the tool is.
That said I bought a Series X primarily because it lets me store and play throwaway stuff like Forza or COD that would otherwise take up 100 gb that are better utilized for shit like BeamNG and AC mods.

>>26178707
yes it's super easy
go to online but don't join a server yet
find a car with a unique cash value (brz, skylines are good) and search decimal 4byte, exact value for the cost of the car.
if your price isn't unique enough as a number you'll get a lot of garbage entries so go and highlight the car you want in the menu and then deselect it (this will clear more garbage out of the code list) then hit "next scan" and you should get just the price entries for that car.

go and change the memory addresses from the price of the car you want to a unique number that you want to pay. so if you picked the beetle, it costs 18000, so you change all the 18000 memory locations to something small like "1742"
the game calculates the sell prices of the car from a fraction of the buy price and if it's really low the game just gives you all the money back. so buy your 1,742 dollar beetle and go to the sell page

now go back to cheat engine and search for 1742. change all the entries to 999999999. 999 mil is the largest possible bank value so if you have some money already you'll probably wanna pick a slightly lower amount. then sell the car. you will get 999 mil credits. but don't just hop online yet, go and buy a few cars to legitimize your inventory. then quit the game to the main menu (clears the cheats from memory) and rejoin the MP mode. you should have a bajillion creds.

>>26179496
if you just want a bugatti anyway replace the itemid of another car with 12789960
this will make a partless chiron for the cost of whatever car you swapped in, you will also need to swap the chiron's rear bumper (6577034), roof (42193573), and boot (32547078)

a good car to use for this is the crown vic (41865083) because it has the same classes of parts: rear bumper (58903665), boot (38479285), and roof (65388320)

in cheat engine, search the crown vic's ids first and replace the vic and its parts with the chirons ids. then buy the "crown vic" in the dealership. it will be a fleet white bugatti chiron death kart with the vic's 4.6 modular in it.
to make it look less sus, you then go to the body modification menu and buy the rest of the stock parts. leave the rear drum brakes if you want for lulz. to make it a real chiron you can then go to the engine swap menu and buy the stock engine. or don't, and drag your nuts over noobs in b-class with your salvage title hypercar.
there are other, simpler ways of cheating yourself a locked car, but i particularly like this method because it paints the car you want in the color of the car you replaced it with, without having to use the wrap system. i have challengers in white, plum crazy, and bayside blue. naturally i had to leave the rb26 in the r34 swapped one.

you can also combine this method with enginestructure swaps, which is how i made this w16 chally. i swapped the crown vic's enginestructure for the chiron's then the vic item id was swapped with the chally. result: fleet white w16 retard rocket.

>>26183223
Not him, pre-war anon here again. Sorry for filling the bait thread. I did some time on an (admittedly somewhat unorthadox) racing team a couple summers ago. Like >>26183077 said, racing teams are largely volunteer work. If you're serious about wanting to join one, IMO the best way to get on one is to go to larger racing events and just get your name out as much as possible. Stop in at tents and ask if they need help with dumb menial shit. Shoot the shit with the guys about the car. This is assuming you sort of know your way around cars already and are not a total sperg. Most will say no, but occasionally, you'll be in the right place at the right time and you can jam your foot in the door. I know a couple of buddies who got on teams doing stuff like that and they had a blast all summer. Again though, they're making pretty much no money.

If you want to make money around race cars, then you have to talk to the track prep guys. Depending on company size and clients, you can actually make a pretty good bit of cash doing track support. But, you better be fucking excellent at making stuff work in a pinch, wrenching quickly and effectively, and make very few mistakes under pressure. It's legitimately a pretty tough job, even at the more amateur level races. Definitely something you have to work your way up to IMO, but those jobs are out there.

posts.sub: How much does it cost to put legitimately good speakers in a car?
posts.com:
My 2017 Mustang has the best speakers of any car I owned. Actually my 2008 Chrysler 300 might have been better...or my 2007 Range Rover Sport Supercharged.

Anyways, the Mustang is in recent memory. I love listening to music in it. It sets the vibe for a drive so well.

On the other hand, my 2015 Crosstrek daily driver has dogshit speakers. Theoretically, how much would it cost to have decent speakers like any of the other cars I mentioned installed in my car?

I could probably do all the work myself. But what products would I need?

Honestly I don't think I'd want to own any more cars with shitty stereo systems. I have a motorcycle and obviously I either have my Cardo speakers or my MEE M6 Pro IEM's. But at least on the bike the visceral experience steals the show. In a car, it's usually the audio that's the icing on the cake.

>How much does it cost to put legitimately good speakers in a car?
About as much as the speakers cost plus probably a few bucks for tools like a plastic wedge or something to remove the door panels or whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26184041
If you're only upgrading the existing speakers and are not adding anything else, then you really don't need to spend all that much. No idea what it would be in freedom land, but I bought these (https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B07QH6BXPY) to go in my Miata, and they're fine.

I find that the environment the speakers are in tend to make more of a difference per dollar than the speaker itself, so if your mustang has good sound, see if ford have put anything around or behind the speakers and try to copy it on your 300. A $500 speaker in open air will probably sound shitty compared to a $50 speaker in a well designed environment, so far as I can tell.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26155512
International is the cheap fleet truck, they’re shitty. Everything is plastic and the smell of the plastic offgassing is so bad that you need to park with the windows open the first year of the truck’s life

Freightliner is probably #2 from the bottom. They’re solid company trucks, better than International, but nothing special. They might give you one piece of fake wood trim across the dash.

Kenworth is like Peterbilt Jr, the company doesn’t mind spending a couple extra bucks to have good lookin trucks on the road. Our Kenworths are way more comfy than Internationals of the same era.

Peterbilt is like Kenworth but even more of the Murrican Trucker. Tons of gauges with chrome rings around them, for owner-ops and companies that want to have lots of chrome on the road.

Western Star is a more rare one, all custom built trucks, like Peterbilt but more exclusive for the real super truckers.

Volvo is like if Freightliner cared about drivers. I love driving Volvos, lots of extra little touches, like Peterbilt but with a modern Yuro touch. Not sure if servicing them is so easy though.

Mack is a real small market share these days, not sure what happened to them. I saw like zero new Macks between 2000 and maybe 2015. They’re about on par with Kenworth, some chrome and not the cheapest looking, but they’re like 1% or less of trucks on the road so probably not great if you need service in the middle of the country.

>>26176691
Model T wasn't the first gas car. Before the Model T which opened up car ownership to the middle class of the era, cars had been an expensive impractical novelty for the upper class for about 20 years. Even once the Model T arrived there really wasn't infrastructure to support it, so Ford sold people the ability to make fuel for it at home so they could drive around, even if it was just in their local area. It took a while longer for the prices to really come down, and for the infrastructure to be at a point where car ownership wasn't just something for well to do early adopters interested in new technology.

Tesla Roadster, the first modern EV, which like those first gas cars was an expensive novelty of the upper class, was only 14 years ago.
Over that time the price for ~60kWh EVs has come down from $80k to $25k, and that $25k car is a lot more practical vehicle for about the same inflation adjusted price as the first Model T.
Also remember, by modern standards the Model T wouldn't be a car with its 45mph top speed. It would be a UTV, and there are comparable cheap electric UTVs already on the market.

>>26176858
>So you finally admit it's more like a hybrid than a BEV.
I'm not sure why you think this is a 'gotcha'. Hybrid Electric Vehicles, especially Plug In Hybrid Electric Vehicles are Electric Vehicles. Nobody gets caught up on the 'purity' of the powertrain, especially when talking about powertrain development to conform to the reality of racing rulebooks which allow hydrogen refueling but not battery swapping. One of the advantages of electric powertrains is their ability to take advantage of multiple sources of electricity, and an endurance racing EV using a swappable high capacity battery would still have a similar design with a buffer battery for peak performance, and the KERS.

>will last for less than half an hour at the average power consumption of 120 kW (that's 160 horsepower), leaving you with fuel-cell's 85 kW (114 hp)
Except that's not how it works. The 85kW fuel cell is continually generating electricity, so any time the car is drawing more power than that the fuel cell can provide its drawing on the power stored in the buffer battery, and any time the car is drawing less power than that, the fuel cell is filling the buffer battery back up. Also any time the car is decelerating its using the KERS to put energy back into the buffer battery.
As I said, this is very similar to how endurance racing performance hybrids work, and why they're so dominant because the battery acts as a buffer to keep the generator in a lower stress state.

Considering how much higher performance the N Vision 74's motors are, and how much better the Kinetic Energy Recovery they can provide is compared to the Prius, it would still almost certainly be able to outpace it. Even the new sportier Prius.
Keep in mind the Hyundai car we're talking about isn't a racing optimized vehicle built to be lightweight, its a retro luxury concept show car for this powertrain.
If Hyundai do decide to take this powertrain to LeMans it will almost certainly be in a prototype shell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26177373
>Electric motors in transmissionless vehicles
There are no "transmissionless" vehicles. They have fixed gear transmissions. This works for electric motors because their torque band is so wide. Enough to manage the whole range of normal speeds a typical vehicle will be driven. Which is why the only vehicles that need specially designed motors with varied windings or multiple transmissions are ones with top speeds over about 140mph.

>it's a hybrid electric vehicle
Its not because Fuel Cells are a fully electric powertrain element. Hybrids are hybrids because there are two separate dissimilar powertrains.
Every Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle must have a hydrogen tank, fuel cell stack, battery, and an electric motor. The fuel cell provides a constant electrical current, the battery takes that current and buffers it to provide peak power on demand and handles kinetic energy recovery from the electric motor.
The only difference with the Hyundai concept compared to the Toyota Mirai FCEV is that the buffer battery is much larger, 60kWh vs 8kWh, giving it the ability to drive in a full battery electric mode without needing to use hydrogen in daily use.
Which is a big deal when hydrogen costs the equivalent of $15 a gallon.

Your nitpicks are based on your ignorance of the technology. My post comparing EVs to ICE was in terms of the limitations in stored energy currently.
That is the one advantage internal combustion has right now. The ability to easily store 1MWh in an endurance racing fuel tank, and get another 1MWh relatively quickly.
BEVs typically have less than 100kWh, one tenth the stored energy, and lack the equivalent of an endurance racing fuel tank.
This is the reason why Fuel Cell Range Extending technology is in the process of being approved for endurance racing.
It allows for fully electric vehicles with comparable range and refueling times.

>>26179964
Its not entirely useless. At the very least It explains why some numbers like 34, 68, 100, or 200kWh get thrown around a lot for EVs, as that is 1, 2, 3, and 6 gallon equivalents.
Also why EVs have limited range, and why they're so dependent on efficiency. Most gas cars with 400 or 500 kWh fuel tanks won't even notice the difference between 1000 Wh/mi (30mpg) and 1700 Wh/mi (20mpg), but for an EV with only the equivalent of 2 or 3 gallons of gas its going to really get hurt on range if they only achieve 333 Wh/mi (100mpge) vs the usual 250 Wh/mi (135mpge) especially when charging infrastructure isn't nearly as common as gas infrastructure.

So for instance in the discussion about track use a 20% efficient gas car with a 30 gallon extended range endurance fuel tank has about 1MWh of stored energy, and gets about 200kWh of useful work out of it.
Which is why Porsche, BMW, Tesla and other EV companies are talking about 200kWh as their target for the next-generation of performance EVs.
Or why 12kg hydrogen tanks are getting talked about because with 400kWh of stored energy and 50% efficient fuel cells they also result in about 200kWh of output.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26182314
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TptzkkbC1vE

High-end enthusiast cars are doing quite well with the cutting edge of electric powertrain technology.
That technology just takes time to come down in price to the general public. Especially when most "Enthusiasts" here refuse to buy cars, and just complain about the industry making cars that aren't for them.

>retain it's output between 100% and 10%
That's already been solved, its why newer electric cars have 800v or 1000v battery architectures instead of 400v even if the motors are 400v because that means voltage fading is less likely to affect power output.

The only current compromises, are just the fact that EVs can't carry that much stored energy, or refill as quickly as gas cars.
But the second gets mostly solved off-track by better infrastructure being rolled out, and current batteries are already enough for most enthusiast level events.
Why carry around a 200kWh battery pack that weighs 400kg even with the best cells, when a 60kWh pack is all you need to get through a track day session?

Fine, I guess I'll have to post it again.
From Wikipedia:
"Initial layout and design elements for the 86 were presented by Toyota using its "FT" (Future Toyota) concept car nomenclature. The first was the Toyota FT-HS, which was presented at the North American International Auto Show in 2007. It had a front engine, rear-wheel drive layout and 2+2 seating and was powered by a V6 engine with hybrid electric assistance. In 2008, Toyota bought 16.5% of Fuji Heavy Industries, which includes the Subaru automotive brand.[8] Toyota, led by project leader Tetsuya Tada,[9] then invited Subaru to partner in the project, by co-developing the new D-4S boxer engine.[10] The offer, which conflicted with Subaru's reputation for high performance all-wheel drive (AWD) cars, was rejected. The project came to a six-month halt before Toyota invited journalists and Subaru engineers to test a developmental prototype. Following the test, Subaru agreed to become further involved in development.[11]


Toyota FT-86 Concept (2009)
The collaboration produced a concept car, the FT-86 Concept, which debuted at the Tokyo Motor Show in October 2009. Smaller than the FT-HS, the design of the FT-86 was further refined by Toyota's ED2 design studio while the hybrid V6 powerplant was replaced by the new D-4S boxer. Subaru provided the chassis, modifying it from their Impreza. The custom red paint was based on the backside of a Japanese macaque.[12]

At the 2010 Tokyo Motor Show, Toyota launched its G Sports line of aftermarket accessories, along with the FT-86 G Sports concept car. It featured G Sports carbon fibre panels, a vented bonnet, rear wing, 19 in (48 cm) wheels, Recaro race seats, and an interior rollcage.[13] The D-4S engine also added a turbocharger.[14]

In 2011, Toyota and Subaru unveiled five near-production concept cars to show their progress with the project."

>>26182646
It's probably a T34 (5spd OD) or a T35 (5spd close-ratio no OD). 1st gear is non-synchro, so you'll have to double-clutch, but the IH motors are torquers, that'll idle down to 300rpm, so you can probably pull out in 2nd. On one hand, 110,000 miles is nothing for a commercial 345. On the other, IH's generally have the balls beat off them, although this one looks pretty good. Parts will be hard to get - that motor went out of production 43 years ago. The radiator hoses, alone, are gigantic. It can take weeks to find one. Keep it in mind. Yeah I'd fucking buy it in a heartbeat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26183175
The issue is ICE cars are already so incredibly inefficient and they have so much stored energy, they can afford to not be very aerodynamically efficient. The little bits of gains you're going to make, 10 Watt hours here, 20 Wh there aren't going to make a big difference when you're burning through 1350 Wh every mile at 62 and you have 500 kWh of stored energy in your fuel tank.

EVs, BEVs especially, by contrast have so little stored energy, usually 100 kWh or less for a BEV and 200kWh or less for a FCEV, they need to save every bit of energy they can.
10 Wh or 20 Wh here or there can add up to make a fairly substantial difference when the electric motor is using 200 Wh/mi at 62 instead of 250.

If you're a fan of classic super-aero looks like I am its a welcome trend. Clean lines with, actually functional aero features.
Even the tech inside the car isn't necessarily useless. If a bit of electronics uses 5 watts, but it saves 15 watts at speed, that's a gain.
The other stuff like screens instead of physical dials are happening because they're cheaper and they're required by law.

The kind of cars you're asking for aren't going to happen until batteries or hydrogen storage are a lot more mature, and can store a lot more energy.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26183215
Current BEVs aren't really any heavier than their internal combustion competition, and many next-generation BEVs are lighter weight precisely because of that energy saving.

Even when you do go lighter, its still worth thinking about every watt just because of how little energy batteries, especially cheap batteries can store and the gains can be massive.
Every watt hour a mile you can save, is watt hour of battery you don't have to carry around all the time for the same range.

Put 100kWh battery in a 3 mile a kWh car and you can only drive 300 miles. Put that exact same battery in a car that does 5 or 6 miles a kWh, and you've got a car that can drive significantly farther with the same stored energy. Or you can get the same range or better out of just a 60kWh battery.

You're just not thinking about the real weight of the problem.
If you want 300 miles of range out of a car with barn door aero that uses more energy to push through the air at speed, you're going to easily need a 120kWh battery. At speed, aero is the killer not weight.
Regardless of how lightweight you make the rest of the car, with the best and most expensive batteries today that's 600kg.
So bad aero also winds up being counterproductive if your goal is lighter weight.

Every watt hour a mile you can shave off, is battery mass you don't need to cart around. If you can average 5 miles a kWh, then you only need 60kWh of battery for the same range, and you can still be lighter weight even using cheaper less dense cells.

No one wants their OEM glass to be broken.

Cars naturally have OEM windows when new. OEM glass in modern cars is both harder to reduce star-chipping and laminated to reduce road noise transmission. Have you gone thru a sandstorm only to have those super tiny bright specks appear on a sunny day? The larger sand particles made ultra tiny chips in soft glass.

The other problem is electronic glass where not only defrosters are installed, but the radio antenna is also there. Such windows, front or back, are expensive to replace. For example, my front windshield, made of electronic low-road-noise glass, costs over $1000 to replace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26181761
Okay so I may be a paranoid little retard but better safe than sorry. Here are some essentials I think everyone should have:

1. Dashcam. I got an Apeman C550 for $48 a few months ago and that small amount could save the entire value of the car if some /o/ user t-bones you because they ran a red light while drunk driving and then tries to say that you were the one that ran the red light. Also good for recording funny things you see on the road.

2. Jump pack. Dirt cheap for being able to save you from needing to ask for a jump from some random schitzo in a remote parking lot.

3. Work gloves, mallet, headlamp, and other small things that make changing a wheel on the side of the road easier.

4. In the winter: Cold weather sleeping bag, granola bars or something similar, blanket, and anything else you need to wait out a storm, or at least wait for the plow/salt trucks to come by.

5. 12V Air compressor. Your excellent car indicates that you are in Europe so you do not have Harbor Freight but I imagine you can get one easily.


Non-Essential stuff that I like to have:

1.Pen and post-it notes to write down license plates or other important info quickly

2. Hidden backup coin reserve for parking meters or car washes

3. Tape measure to see if stuff fits in my vehicle before lifting it

4. Duct tape to make temporary repairs if needed

5. Rain jacket or one of those compact emergency ponchos

6. Phone holder if you want one

7. In winter I like to bring a small snow shovel in case I have to dig out of a parking space or snowbank

8. Straps to secure cargo (if I don't leave them in there all the time I might forget them when I really need them)

9. Recreational McNuke (for road rage incidents)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26174170
Reverse parking is an intelligence test. Incredibly simple, yet it works on multiple levels.
For one it tests if you have a concept of delayed reward. Reverse parking is slightly more difficult and time consuming than forward parking for a novice. Yet when you come to leave, driving forwards out of a space onto a busy street or parking lot is infinitely easier than backing out and being unable to see what's coming. The payoff is well worth it.
But that's not all
Reverse parking is easier than forward once you practice, but more difficult initially. So it is also a laziness test. Someone who gives no shits about what is better in the long run or improving themselves will always choose the lazy option of badly forward parking because it is "easier and quicker", and they will spend their entire life doing that.
For those that aren't filtered by the laziness and intelligence test it actually works out even better once you practice due to the way cars turn. While going forwards the rear end follows the front and cuts the corner trailing behind you. You have little control over this. So to forward park properly, you have to swing the front out wide (which you don't always have room for) so that the rear end can cut the corner and end up in the right place. Most forward parkers are too stupid to realise this, so they end up backing out and in again multiple times or they just leave the car at a stupid angle they initially pulled in at.
On the contrary, while going backwards your car becomes rear steering. By thinking ahead you can make very tight turns and still end up placing the rear of the car exactly where it needs to be then correcting the placement of the front of the car in the same motion

Tl;dr being able to rear-park is a retard test

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are a few reasons why backing into a parking space may be considered better than driving into a parking space head-on:

>Improved visibility:
When you reverse park, you have a better view of your surroundings because you are facing the opposite direction. This can make it easier to spot pedestrians, other vehicles, and other potential hazards.

>Easier exit:
When you reverse park, it is easier and quicker to exit the parking space because you are already facing the direction you need to go. This can be especially helpful if you are in a crowded or busy parking lot.

>Increased safety:
Reverse parking can also be safer because you are less likely to hit something while backing up than you are while driving forward. This is because you have a better view of what is behind you when you are backing up, and you can use your rearview and side mirrors to check for obstacles.

>Better control:
When you reverse park, you have better control over the vehicle because you are using the reverse gear. This can be especially helpful for drivers who are not comfortable maneuvering their vehicle in tight spaces.

>>26169944
britbong here. much more control than automatic. if you actually enjoy driving you'll like it a lot. you get used to using clutch in traffic, really not bad at all after you get accustomed to it - it'll be second nature.
and you get to do fun things like rev matching which is extremely satisfying when it clicks. even (potentially, idk how you drive) better gas milage cause you can choose what gear you feel suits the situation best, instead of a computer. good anti theft device in usa as well :^)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26169944
Just try out a manual car and decide for yourself, if you have any friend who has one. You get more control, it's more direct, it's more fun. You can do it slow, you can do it fast, you can give yourself a little bit of oversteer by changing gear too rough in the corner on purpose, you can give yourself a nice bit of extra turn-in by heel-toeing and putting lower gear for extra engine braking, or you can just go nice and smooth and enjoy your own abilities to do that. Pulling off a nice and smooth rev-match is properly pleasant.

That being said, I've got no idea, I never drove a single automatic in my life because it's just not a thing in EU unless you have a very modern car. All of shitboxes in my family were always manual, my first car was manual, my miat was manual, my current car is manual. When people mention that manuals are bothersome in traffic, i always scratch my head because I've no idea what the problem is. Just use the clutch a lot, what's the big deal? Then again, I believe you guys that autos may be more comfy in those situations, it's just that I cannot imagine how the other side of the argument is like. But then again, regarding that, you're not enjoying cars in start-stop traffic anyway, so why not optimize your happiness for twisties where manual excels?

Manual can be challenging but it rewards you for getting better. I heel toe downshift every time I drive, and I do it any chance I get and I’ve become very smooth now. It’s one of the best feelings as a driver.

It was absolutely worth it and driving is 3-4x funner—every time I drive, not just when I’m flooring it on an on ramp or whatever. No regrets. I will always strive to have a manual car in my lineup.

my friend's car has a code for excessive vacuum on the evap system. he also mentioned that when he fills up with gas the car takes 5-10 tries to start and the car reeks like gas afterwards. I was thinking the purge valve because if the purge valve is stuck open and the gas he's putting in the tank is pushing all the vapor through the valve into the intake he'd have to crank it for a while to get rid of all the fuel vapor enough to get the thing to have the right air fuel ratio to start. the only explanation i could think of for the fuel smell is that the pressurized vapor is making its way towards atmosphere out of the manifold and throttle body into the air outside.
another reason i think it may be the purge valve is that the scan tool was reading 0% purge valve operation at idle, but the commanded purge valve operation fluctuated between 0 and 16% at idle, which tells me the valve is not doing what the ecu wants it to do. (im assuming if this theory is correct that 0% must mean fully open?). also, when we used the scan tool to manually open and shut the vent valve, when we forced the vent valve to the "on" position the engine would stumble and almost stall out for a second. but im not sure if "on" = open or closed. thoughts?

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26182911
0% must mean close… from an armchair mechanic. I don’t think it’s going to open a ton at idle because the low rpm engine won’t be able to burn all that vapor,

On sounds open and you made it too rich. The purge valves get leaky, try to pull a vacuum with the engine off and see if it holds. If it’s leaky, you’re probably getting way more vapor in there than you should, hence the problem starting until you clear some of that vapor out.

How do you convince anyone in their mid 20s to take their pickup truck off road? I have a friend with a OBS F350 crew cab 7.3 4x4 manual diesel.
Claims the solid front axle is terrible off road, any truth in that? I honestly struggle to understand why he purchased that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170736
solid front axle is strong and flexes well. except in a diesel.
diesels are fuckheavy and sink in mud and snow

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170736
The F350 uses radius control arms up front. They don't flex as well as three or four link but are more stable on the highway and better at handling heavy loads. From the factory most solid front axle pickup trucks are tuned for highway, not off road.

Also the idea that solid front axle is better for off road comes form its ability to easily be modified to flex with suspension upgrades. IFS can be very expensive and complicated to achieve the same flex you can easily get out of a solid axle.

Got it back together for a quick drive. The good news is that the engine runs strong, the transmission is strong, the oil seals and gaskets held, no more oil leaks.

The bad news is that it runs hot when you push it on the highway, the heater core plugged up, and there is loud accessory pulley noise.

So it's going back in the garage to be taken apart once again this time to replace the water pump, thermostat, all coolant hoses, and serpentine belt. Replacing the timing chain and harmonic balancer as well.

This thing is such a piece of shit. But it's MY piece of shit, and this vehicle is endearing somehow. It's got soul.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26178583
Literally the best value off road capable suv right now. They're built like tanks and there is no meme tax like with XJs or Land Cruisers.

I own both the X here >>26174103 and the old XJ in OP. Had a chance to get to work on both.

The 1st gen Xterras are built more solidly. The H233b rear axles are much stronger than anything that came in an XJ, the front and rear diffs are stronger. The IFS is very solid. Body on frame. The drivelines are every bit as reliable.

02-04 were the best years for the 1st gen Xterras. The engines made a little more power, and the transmissions were beefed up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170157
>>26170204
1. inspect oil level and check for water in oil
1a. if there's water you're fucked
2. find out if the engine turns by hand.
2a. if it doesn't, do 3 and 4 then come back in a day or two
3. remove and inspect spark plugs
4. put oil in plug holes
5. (re)install all but 1 plug
6. install battery
6a. watch for big spark when connecting battery
6b. look/listen/smell for burning when connecting battery
7. spin engine via starter motor
7a. listen to how engine is spinning (clunks, rattles, lunging)
7b. check oil pressure while cranking if possible
8. pull a spark plug and check spark
9. there won't be any spark
10. remove distributor cap and rotor
11. file points until you get spark back
12. reassemble rotor, cap, and put plug back
13. disconnect fuel line
14. bottle feed some gas down the carb
15. now it'll fire
16. feed some more gas into the float bowl
17. see if it'll idle
17a. if it doesn't, rebuild carb
18. plumb in alternate fuel tank
19. if it idles, make sure there's water in the radiator
19a. if there isn't, put water in and see where it leaks
19b. fix leaks
20. air up/replace tires
21. drive.

1. Clean it out, inspect status of rust deterioration.
2. Inspect for what's missing, is it complete
3. See if the steering and wheels turn, if it can be pushed around
4. Is the engine locked up? Does it spin freely? Check status of all fluids.
5. Disconnect fuel system, see if it'll fire off with starting fluid if all the above is good.
6. If it won't fire, start diagnosing ignition/electrical/spark system. Then you get into the nitty gritty of parts replacement/rebuilding

>>26173889
Roadtripping home for the holidays. I was going to spend the entire week down south with the family. I took both my pets so I didn't have to get anyone to watch them while I was gone. The cat was in a carrier, so it made it easy to throw her out of the car.
Fire extinguisher I had in the car was not nearly enough to put out 10+ gallons of gas on fire. It killed it for a few seconds, but it flared right back up. When I knew it was a loss, I just started pulling everything out that I could. I know cars can be replaced, but it doesn't make it sting any less. Literally any other type of fire scenario, I could have handled, but the exploded tire sheared off the line connection at the tank and gas was everywhere. Those were brand fucking new Cokers too, it's not like they were old tires that were ready to blow. I'm pretty crushed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26177514
We almost had a fire when were going out to test the new electric fan installed on a modelA. Fired it up and the glass fuel filter installed along the frame rail shattered from vibration. I had run those on a few different vehicles and never had a problem. If you are running one I would replace it with a disposable. It was spraying fuel right next to the exhaust and would have been a catastrophic disaster. It was still leaking when the engine was shut off because the tank is higher than the pump and line up front. Got to remember to get some bigger fire extinguishers and keep them in all cars and shop. I know of a few guys that lost some really nice builds because of a fuel leak or electrical fire. Insurance fight for one guy was bad, even though he had agreed value coverage, they tried to depreciate the 1932 truck because he didn’t provide a YEARLY appraisal. The guy’s argument was “ how much do you think a 1932 ford truck depreciates in 8 years????” I think he came to an agreement and bought the truck back. Camaro dude, don’t know it your later model second generation has them, but my 72 and 73 Camaros had two pieces of fuel line that connected the hard lines at the front subframe rail. They are only a few inches long but are kind of out of sight and don’t usually get maintained and changed.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26177450
That's honestly the point. It's to learn from a worst case scenario. If I can learn it all from this rusted POS, and even learn how to rebuild an engine from the most famous and practical engine of all time (Ford Lima Inline 4cyl), then I'd be ready for most circumstances. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26179184
The short version is that the oiling system prioritize the crank.

The long version is the oil is pumped up from the oil filter on the left front, then diagonally across the front to the right lifter gallery, then down that gallery towards the rear of the block, across the rear of the engine (which is where the oil pressure sender is) then up the left side gallery. The crank is oiled by channels drilled up to the lifter gallery and crossovers depending on main bearing position. This allows a significant amount of pressure and volume loss around the lifters which is exasperated by wear resulting from the side-thrust loads of the angled pushrods. The fix is a lifter bore bushing kit that's now easily available and can be installed at home where it used to take a machine shop and custom bushings to fix.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Oh, and the other Cleveland issue is the "Chinese lantern" cylinder walls.

The design was a thin-wall casting to begin with and apparently there was significant core shift during casting that took cylinder wall thickness down to the minimum for performance in several areas. Add in losses over the last 50 years and it's now difficult to find a Cleveland block in good enough condition for a Sunday drive let alone big power which is how Clevors came about.

>>26180091
The M is built off the 400 block which has a 10.2(17?) deck height while the C has a 9.2 inch deck (the W is 9.5 fwiw). The 400 main bearing diameter is 3 inches where the C is 2.75. Most 400's have the 429/460 bellhousing pattern while the C has the small block pattern. There is small amount of 400's that had the small block pattern. This number was so small they were considered to be myths for decades.

posts.name: Dracula
posts.com:
>>26180424
It's that if you follow the shop manual you'll get 5 reverse gears and 1 forward. They sourced the transmission from the Renault Alpine and mounted it 180 and swapped a gear so that it has 5 reverse and 1 forward gear. When they copied the service procedure, they omitted the gear swap since Renault didn't have it in their manual and published all the factory service literature incorrectly. This never got fixed since DMC went under and most transmissions never needed a rebuild until the '90s.

>The car gets hot in traffic. Dunno if it's because that's just what old cars do, or if it's something else. There's definitely oil in the coolant though, because

>The head was only torqued to about 32 ft-lbs, when spec is 63. I torqued the head, and the breather tube stopped spitting fumes and the car stopped burning oil. Funny that, started holding temperature longer too

>The car had no thermostat in it, due to aforementioned overheating, which was primarily caused by

Having driven one of them, they aren't supposed to get that hot. Your head gasket is likely going bad or was compromised by the low torque. Clean that up and flush the radiator and block and it should run cool. Those I8s can displace a LOT of heat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26183097
CFM flow numbers will let you know almost the exact horsepower the motor will make, assuming you run a good exhaust and intake and carb or otherwise choke it.
Intake CFM x .26= theoretical horsepower x percent exhaust flow.
Example: 325x.26= 84.5 hp per cylinder
84.5 x 8= 676. Times 8 for 8 cylinders
Say your head flow 85% of what the intake flow on the exhaust side.
676x .85= 574.6 HP.
This is why good heads are important if you want to make power. It’s also why head ported that can produce flow numbers can make a very good living. That’s also why SBC race heads have 2.05” or 2.08” intake valves.
Edelbrock makes good stuff, but it is expensive. They tend to put packages together and advertise their package horsepower. They make ok power but never the power that a ported AFR, Brodix, Trick Flow, or others make. For one reason is their port cc size is usually on the smaller side like 180 or 295cc when the others make monster ports of 220-240cc. A 240cc Small block would make great peak power but wouldn’t drive well on the street. I once got to port on a set of new Brodix heads, asked the owner what they were going on and he replied “Earnhardt’s car” He had me hog them way out, I was afraid to fuck up an over $1,000 bare casting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26183599
Amps are a function of voltage over resistance. A starter has a low resistance so the battery is able to deliver lots of current. A smaller battery has higher internal resistance so it would interfere with the starting. A diode has basically infinite resistance in the reverse direction so 12V, no matter how high the amperage capacity of the batteries, will not conduct through. Diodes do have a breakdown voltage but unless OP hooked up a 200V hybrid battery directly to his car battery he wouldn't exceed that limit.

>>26175302
I have a newer 5th gen, have had it for 4 years now. Drove it multiple times on long 1500+ mile road trips and have gone in snow and rock crawled around the Southwest. It's a good reliable adventure vehicle, one that's reliable simply because it's a relic with tech from 2001-2005ish, despite being sold new today. It's probably the most analog car you can buy new off the dealer lot today if that's your thing. It's been supremely reliable, despite guzzling fuel at a rate of 18-19 mpg on average.

Other than that, this car has some severe drawbacks. It absolutely guzzles fuel, the ride is okay but not cushy or luxurious by any means, the stock new tires were absolute garbage and I went through several changes before settling on a Michelin Defender LTX's as an overall highway and offroad/snow ready tire. It has lots of road and wind noise on long highway trips but holy fuck that roll-down window makes beautiful days that much more enjoyable to drive in. I have the model with the KDSS which is night and day compared to models without it when handling turns, I'm very glad I got it.

When I bought my TRDOR it was $38k OTD, but for the prices they're charging nowadays for such an outdated platform and drivetrain, it is questionable. Knowing the next gen 4Runner has a high chance of being made in Mexico and being turbocharged, I'll probably keep this for an extended time and hope it appreciates in the future or keep it forever as parts will probably be plentiful.

Most diesels run lean even at peak output unless it is one of those tards who tuned theirs to spew smoke. The biggest advantage of a diesel behind compression is that they regulate power with fuel. A diesel just pulls in atmospheric pressure or higher constantly and varies the fuel added according to the power demanded.

They cheated for NOx emissions which is not because diesel is inherently dirty, but because it burns lean as I stated above. When the mixture is lean all the time like in a diesel the extra oxygen combusts nitrogen in the air and produces NOx.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26182333
Gasoline can run lean of peak instead, as that reduces combustion temps much like running rich of peak. This was commonly done in WWII aircraift, for instance, in order to save on fuel. But those planes had lots of cylinders so uneven firing strength from cylinder to cylinder was less relevant than in a passenger car with only a handful of cylinders, and also they didn't have to worry about NOx emissions or anything. Modern engine management makes this more possible, although I haven't heard of a whole lot of advancements useful to put into production beyond systems like skyactive or other so-called "lean burn" approaches.

I have to say that the BMW 335D with the M57 diesel engine is quite possibly the best car to come off an assembly line. This car has it all: performance, luxury, and style. And for the price, it's an absolute steal.

First of all, the M57 diesel engine is a powerhouse. It's a 3.0-liter inline-six engine that produces an impressive 265 horsepower and 425 lb-ft of torque. This means that the 335D has plenty of power for both city driving and highway cruising. Plus, the diesel engine provides excellent fuel economy, with an EPA-rated 28 mpg in the city and 38 mpg on the highway.

In terms of luxury and style, the BMW 335D is hard to beat. It has a sleek and sophisticated exterior, with a body that is both aerodynamic and eye-catching. The interior is equally impressive, with high-quality materials and a host of high-tech features. Plus, the car has a comfortable and spacious cabin that makes it a joy to drive.

Overall, the BMW 335D with the M57 diesel engine is the ultimate car for the price. It's an amazing blend of performance, luxury, and style, and it's a car that any enthusiast would be proud to own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How do you guys center stickers? Like if I want to center one on my rear windshield, any tricks/tips?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164256
Use a piece of cord*. upper left corner to lower right corner. Mark the approximate center with a liquid chalk pen or something else thats easily removable.
Repeat between upper right corner to lower left corner. X now marks the exact center of your windshield.
*Cord because modern windshields aren't flat surfaces. Cord follows the form.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
After that you measure height and width of your sticker. Divide both values by 2 and you got the center of your stigger too
For example:
Sticker width is 10 inches then 5 inches is the center.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
Alternatively you can use masking tape instead of cord. Either way: Don't get distracted by the fact you won't see a straight line. That's due to the mentioned curvature of the windshield.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26171716
>"open auto stipulation" is the biggest horse shit thing i've ever read

Depends on the bank's lending algo, in general the number of allowable open auto loans is based on DTI (debt to income ratio) but there's a lot of circumstances where the open auto (and other) stipulations can get throw a wrench in the mix. Computers are stupid and automated approvals fuck up all the time.

For example someone might take home 10k/mo and have two open auto loans where they are paying 500/mo each with no other debt obligations. Clearly they make enough to afford another car payment based on their DTI but if they've only had those two loans open for 6 months or something there's a shitload of banks that will deny them an approval based on their automated algo. In those cases the dealership finance rep has to call the bank rep and negotiate an approval on the phone.

Any time you buy a car for over 10k in cash (down payment or in full) they're required to report it to the IRS. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180983
>They really just want you to keep paying.
That is goal #1 of the bank. They'll bend over backwards with leeway, assistance programs, deferment, all kinds of shit if you actually run into problems and just cannot pay. But if you just stop paying they can and will seize assets. Yes they will repo an underwater car or house or any other tangible asset. They auction it off for whatever they can then alert you of your remaining balance. Then they add interest and fees and send it to collections. That debt is then sold for pennies which then the collections agents attempt to collect whatever they can. The bank writes off the bad deb as tax deductible for them.

The debtor can settle that remaining debt for less because collectors bought it for a really tiny fraction of what is really owed. But what the last guy didn't grasp is just because they lent you money to buy something that is now worth nowhere near what they lent you doesn't mean they automatically call your note and demand you randomly pay. Contracts have a pay schedule. People like Ramsey were using bank loans as OPM to do business deals. They *can* call bank notes when you have open lines of credit for major shit like millions in real estate. They usually give you a 90 day deadline to pay up but its just like balloon payments.

Nissan has bungled its exit from the FIA World Endurance championship as badly as it handled competing in the fiercely competitive sports cars series.

Approximately 40 employees at the Indianapolis-based LMP1 program were notified by e-mail the program had been cancelled Tuesday morning, yet with many of the staffers on vacation for the holidays and away from work e-mail, news of the firing, for some, came from a press release the Japanese brand decided to post in its global newsroom. Those who did turn up for work Tuesday morning were barred access to the building, and senior team officials, who were also caught by surprise, stepped in to call and inform (or confirm) the sudden dismissals for all who worked at the facility.

Nissan's cancelation of the troubled program, just days before Christmas, is the latest chapter in what has been a truly tumultuous journey from concept to race.

Road & Track was present for the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO's debut on Dec. 19, 2014, at Circuit of The Americas, where the radical, front-engine, front-wheel-drive prototype suffered through a troubled introduction that made only modest gains over the next 368 days until the program's termination. https://www.roadandtrack.com/motorsports/news/a27710/nissan-fired-its-lmp1-employees-over-e-mail/

posts.com:
>>26075559
Pretty much..
“Behind the engine and beneath the cockpit is a kinetic energy recovery system using two flywheels developed by Torotrak. The flywheels gain energy from the use of the front brakes then discharges that energy back to the front wheels via a driveshaft running over the top of the combustion engine. The flywheels can also output power to a secondary driveshaft which is connected to a limited-slip differential at the rear of the car which feeds epicyclic gearboxes located in each rear wheel hub, allowing the GT-R to be all-wheel drive if necessary.”

Sound complicated? It should, because it is.

Additionally, while the engine is in front of the driver, it’s also behind the centerline of the front wheels, so it’s more of a front-mid layout. As Bowlby explained in an interview with Racecar Engineering:

“The front tyres on the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO are bigger than the rear tyres – 14 inch wide front vs. 9 inch rear. This is due to the way that mass is distributed in the car. We have moved the weight bias forwards to give us traction for the front-engined, front-wheel drive. We’ve also moved the aero forwards so we’ve moved the capacity of the tyres forward to match the weight distribution. So the aero centre of pressure, the mass centre of gravity and the tyre capacity are all in harmony and that means we have bigger tyres at the front than the rear”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26068883
Mitsubishi Motors completely abandoned RWD cars with the exception of the Starion in the 1980s. This would be one of the many decisions that would bleed the brand over the next few decades.
When the big three of Japan decided to come out with their bespoke luxury brands, Mitsubishi decided there was no need for this despite having basically no clout in the American market, they made fleet and commuter vehicles. This combined with the pathetic 3.0 V6 meant the gussies up Galant known as the Sigma was a failure.
They also gradually fucked up their sports car lineup in the states as well. The DSM cars, Chrysler's FWD sports cars, and the captive import Starion (Chrysler Conquest), occupied slightly varying price levels but were essentially in competition with each other in the same showrooms.
The GTO/3000GT used a twin-turbo version of the 6G72 3.0 V6 in the highest trims. We know now that even this engine struggled to power the AWD system of the over 3500 lb car which wasn't helped by the two turbochargers. What's stranger is that the 6G74 3.5 V6 was dropped in multiple Mitsubishi vehicles, SUVs and sedans, and was able to approach the twin-turbo 6G72 in power in NA form.
During the height of the Fast and Furious tuner hype, Mitsubishi cut corners and made the third generation Eclipse FWD only, but let you have a V6.
The company would spend the 2000s and 2010s producing shitty commuter cars for the states, the market they invested so much into entering through the Chrysler partnership. By the 2010s they were essentially a second class Jap brand like Suzuki and Isuzu.

>>26135292
I used to do this as a high school job. We very rarely fucked with the coiling on anything but starters for big diesels. Not much actually goes wrong with them. Crack it open, replace or rebuild the solenoid, replace the drive if it’s shot, new bushings/bearings, fresh grease and they almost always work.

Weakest point is the solenoid contacts. Usually they’re the first thing to wear out.

>>26129723
I am currently chasing down a couple of issues on my newly acquired '97 F150.
>shifter
I've got a shift indicator that isn't indicating the correct gear and there's a squeaking/plasticy grinding noise when moving the shift lever down through the gears. So far I've replaced the shifter shaft bushings, shifter shaft clamps (the good ole boy I bought it from replaced on of the clamps with an ill-fitting strip of 20GA at some point so that cleaned up the shifter slop considerably), replaced the shifter and retaining pin along with adding a damper to further cut down on slop, blue Loctite'd all the fasteners in the shifter mechanism and torqued to spec, and I've checked the PRNDL mechanism to make sure it is functioning correctly. All of this has improved the feel of the shifter considerably, but no dice on the incorrect indicator and squeaky noise. Through process of elimination I am now convinced that the shift cable needs to be adjusted or replaced. I can watch the mechanism move from the floor and there is no slop. The noise seems to come from close to the firewall where the cable is. Like it is binding up or something.
>heater
I have no heat. I replaced the thermostat and in doing so realized the coolant system badly needs flushed. There's no air in the system so far as I can tell. The vents are blowing cold air so I narrowed the problem down to either a faulty blend knob, blend door actuator, or blend door. Today I removed the blend actuator to test functionality and further narrow down the problem. It functioned when turning the knob so the knob and actuator both work. Around the key that the actuator turns there is black plastic debris which I believe indicates a broken blend door. Tomorrow I am going to be cutting through the dash and plenum behind the glovebox and replacing the door. My hope is that between a coolant system flush, a heater core backflush, a new blend door actuator, and a new blend door heat to the cab can be restored.

>>26150528
I'm the guy that recc'd the chief. Before buying another tool you should make sure your compressor isn't getting cucked by 1/4" fittings and the shitty regulator. Highly recommend replacing all fittings and couplers with 3/8 ends with 1/4 npt threads and a 3/8 regulator. Make sure your hose is 3/8 too. No reason to go to 1/2 as it is too big for not that much gain.
Here's a good kit to get you started - https://a.co/d/bMkscuu
Also TTC video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KBQpaUBMmGw
Whatever you do, DON'T USE MILTON FITTINGS THEY FUCKING SUCK.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26155495
Some shit is easier on certain cars, some shit is harder. Inline engine only has one bank of cylinders so easier for headgaskets and stuff, but an I-6 could have stuff buried behind the firewall. Transverse engines mean you have to go in from the wheel well to do lots of the accessories and belt.

Something like an H6 Subaru with AWD sounds terrible to work on. Pickups and SUVs with V6’s and mid-full size sedans and crossovers or small SUVs with I4’s are both pretty easy for most stuff. But it totally depends on the job and the car because there companies don’t really think about ease of service when building the cars.

>>26130254
I know I'm more than a week late to be updating this blog. But I managed to remove the old throttle cables with a combination of ring spanners, poking utensils and what girls refer to as 'magic hands'. My original plan to just replace the internal cable was foiled by the damaged English (oxford) and their refusal to include any of the cable ends that LITERALLY EVERY SINGLE JAPANESE BIKE USES in their "universal throttle cable kit". Luckily I'm God's favourite NPC so the go to bike bits shop had two (almost) universal throttle cable kits that ( were Japanese and) they sold for the price of one because I was wearing overalls and told them I ride a tiny Honda. I say 'almost universal because while my throttle housing had one M8×1.25 thread that fitted perfectly the throttle return is a M10× 1.25 thread, I figured out I could just drill and tap the end of the old cable. However the only way to buy a M10×1.25 tap on a Sunday is as part of a 40 piece tap and die set at any given hardware store.
But after all of this and some more 'Magic hands' I have a fully functioning bike with zero throttle slack. Those "universal" cables were a mm or two short, so if you as much as breathe on the throttle it revs to 6k. There's no excess tension on the cable it's somehow perfectly to length. And it's great, she feels more responsive than ever, in fact it's soo much better I've almost stopped complaining about the final drive ratio being too short.
Anyway good luck with your oil changes or whatever.

>>26161880
I helped a friend stick an LS into his 95, you can actually very easily convert a DBW to DBC - you need to
>1: Add in the bosses into the intake manifold for the throttle cable bracket OR get a DBC intake. You can steal the nutserts from a junkyard truck and then stick them into your DBW intake which is what we did.
>2: Get a DBC throttle body. If you use a DBW intake manifold, remove the PCV fitting from it and plug the hole.
>3: Run the ISV and TPS wires to the correct pins in the ECU as you would a DBC - you need to get creative with I think 2 of the ground pins - we just used another ground pin that was unused in the ECU that did the same thing.
>4: Tune the ECU such that ETC is disabled (literally 1 bit in the tune haha)
>5: Winrar
As I understand it the DBW ECUs (P59) are preferible to the DBC (P01?) since they support greater tuning options and flex fuel support, in our case we simply used the DBW setup since the 5.3 we used came from an 04 avalanche and it was all included with the junkyard engine (fucking $200!)
We still need to tune out the auto trans code since he's running an NV4500, but it seems to be working for him so far.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162695
Oh yeah I wanted to add the early chevy DBW is hardly a modern interpretation of DBW at all - the throttle and gas pedal talk through the throttle control module with the ECU also talking to it to limit throttle angle - the ECU itself acts very much like a DBC in that sense, only telling the throttle control module things like to limit torque when going too fast/limiter/transmission protection etc. It's not like modern DBW where the entire pedal angle->torque request->add in loss torque->engine load->manifold pressure->throttle angle process is done in the ECU and needs to all work correctly. That's why you can simply tune out DBW on your junkyard LS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162716
You need to hook up a scan tool and find out which cylinder(s) are misfiring. If it's just one or two, swap those plugs and coils (or wires if older car) with another cylinder. If the misfire moves to the cylinder you swapped with you know it's either your coil or plugs and you can swap those to narrow it down. If the misfire doesn't move, it's either your harness or a mechanical problem with the cylinder and you can troubleshoot from there.

ok, spray all the spark plug wires down with water, run the car in the dark. does the misfire get worse when wet? do you see little spark flashes from the wires? if so definitely bad wires. also inspect your spark plugs, if one or more is more fouled or if there are carbon tracks that indicates a problem specifically in that cylinder or with that plug.

>>26164911
>Since I am able to smell unburnt gas out of the exhaust, would I be able to rule out an injector problem?
and not necessarily, a leaking injector will overfuel the cylinder causing it to misfire and stinking up the exhaust. the typical way to check for this is run your engine with a fuel press gauge attached. does the pressure drop rapidly after you switch it off? if so probable stuck injector.

I was looking into finally getting an m12 stubby impact wrench, but I see that Makita has a brushless subcompact for quite a bit cheaper using their 18v battery. Has anyone used both?

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26177645
Don’t get into 12V as your first cordless platform. The 12V stubby is like a replacement for a 1/2” ratchet, it’s not going to do anything you can’t do by hand. There’s a huge difference in power if you get down on some of the mid torque 18V 1/2” guns and they’re only a couple inches long. Plus a compact 18V isn’t much larger than the 12V tools and you can use the $100 batteries on tons of other useful tools.

Also as far as stubby impacts, they’re not that powerful overall, and 90% of the jobs you would grab the stubby for, you could use a 1/4” impact driver with a socket adapter and get the same results. So if you’re just buying into a cordless platform, skip the 12V stubby and check out something like the DeWalt 20V Atomic drill and impact driver kit, they’re real affordable when they go on sale. Then save up and get DeWalt’s newest 20V XR 1/2” mid torque, it’s a beast for the size and you won’t even need a high torque for all but the most stubborn rusted shit. But make sure it’s the newest one because the gen 1 XR mid torque is far less powerful and looks the same.

If you’re a burger, Makita is like #3 of the cordless tool brands as far as reasons to buy. Milwaukee and DeWalt trade places for 1 and 2. Milwaukee is a step ahead on /o/ focused tools, but DeWalt has better sales, plus they just released a ton of new stuff in the past year so Milwaukee better drop some new shit or they will lose that #1 spot. Makita is more expensive like DeWalt and doesn’t have nearly as many /o/ focused tools.

Bosch is just dumb if you’re a burger because it’s like Makita but worse. Kobalt and Ridgid will give you DeWalt quality tools at a good price but they don’t have a huge selection of tools. Ryobi is the budget weekender version, but honestly they’re not bad, their new HP stuff is really good for the money and they have tons of random tools for way less than Milwaukee or DeWalt, plus batteries are more affordable.

Looks like there are two Ryobi HP 1/4” impact drivers, the compact one is $90 right now with 2 batteries and is rated 1700in-lbs, which is nearly 150ft-lbs, so that thing is going to be like 60%-70% the power of the stubby and those compact 1/4” drivers are tiny. They’re great for all those 10mm bolts. And then the other HP impact driver is 2200in-lbs, which is almost 200ft-lbs, so it’s going to be like 80% the power of the stubby. That one is $119, but I’m guessing there is some deal with batteries or another tool to get a better deal on that.

Pic related sort of, that stubby isn’t that much shorter than the larger 1/4” driver and is really close in power, and some of the newest 18V stuff is even more compact, like the M18 Fuel 1/2” mid torque and the new Ridgid 1/2” mid torque and newest Ridgid brushless 1/4” driver are all a little bit shorter than the comparable tools on this table with at least as much power.

>>26180961
Torque and horsepower are incomparable units. Torque is an instantaneous force. Horsepower is work over time. They are not directly comparable, but by automotive convention there was an arbitrary number used to define one against the other even though it's impossible to relate them that way. All it does is makes it natural to plot the two curves against each other for the range of a typical automotive gasoline engine at the time the convention was established.

Don't drop out of high school next time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180979
You'd have to ask him, but I suspect he's talking about logarithmic scales like Richter. In a typical traditional engine setup where maybe care about some kind of racing application where acceleration is really the important thing, then neither torque nor horsepower tells you how fast the engine is going to be able to keep turning faster and faster, let alone how that affects the vehicle's ability to go faster and faster depending on gearing and what range of road speeds you might care about.

But, as a bit of aphoristic wisdom, it is true that you might hope you can keep the engine engine somewhere in the "power band" (i.e. hoursepower) if you want to maintain a high degree of acceleration or at least high speed where more power is needed to overcome fictional losses like wind resistance the rest. Whereas torque is often the more informative thing when it counts for truck or tractor action where you want to be able to begin acceleration from a lower RPM by being able to impel a lot of force on the drive line to get the vehicle up to speed speed where you're better able to expend the total work output (power output) capacity of the engine. It's a bit of a difficult subject if you you're not a math nerd, but I suspect that he's making a reasonably correct analogy that torque tells you more about a categorically lower RPM (think a diesel engine that doesn't typically spin all that fast) vs. a categorically higher RPM (think a gasoline engine where the lighter and faster-burning fuel will tend to expend more of its energy at higher piston speeds.) It's a perpetually difficult subject for these reasons and more, including how a dyno only measures one thing and then tries to infer both figures.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26180959
2035 is because they're considering the development cycles for car generations.
2035 means any cars that started a generation in ~2020 can sell through, as can the generation they've already started working on immediately after the model launch (which won't actually go on sale until ~2027). This means at the end of THAT generation, in 2034, they'll need an EV replacement. Basically they're saying "You don't have to stop work on your next-gen cars, but after that, you better develop an EV"

In Oregon's case, its because it lines up with California's rules.
So no more pure gas cars, BEVs must have at least 150 miles of range (90% of trips without needing to fast charge), and PHEVs must have at least 50 miles of range (80% of trips without needing to run the engine).
2035 is also about 5 years past the point when anyone would be buying new pure gas cars or mild hybrids anyway. Its a feel good law, that in the end won't really have any effect.

Unless of course the car companies refuse to act, in which case the laws passed now are a convenient device for states and the Federal Government to point to when refusing to give these corporations yet another bail out at taxpayer expense.

posts.sub: Trading a 2019 Mazda 3 Hatchback for a 2003-2008 Boxster
posts.com:
Trading a 2019 Mazda 3 Hatchback for a 2003-2008 Boxster? I live in Socal and ride my motorcycle almost all the time. Since I got my car in August I've put like 1200 miles on it. I miss my Miata but just got bit by the Porsche bug. My Mazda 3 hatchback is the premium trim, awd in white with 40k miles. I could probably get like 23k for it and buy a much older Porsche in the process and finally have a car I can enjoy driving when I do have to drive, say into LA or when it's raining super hard or I need groceries. I'm sick of how soulless an experience it is in my Mazda 3, so I have a few questions:

I know initially the IMS bearing had an 8% failure rate and went through a good number of revisions before Porsche changed the design to eliminate it, how much better are the ones after 2000 that still had IMS bearings?

Years to avoid?

How many miles can it be expected to last?

I can do basic monkey shit, oil changes, valve adjustments while I had my Miata, rebuilt the forks on my bike, new fuel pump, threw a new air cleaner and exhaust on my bike, about to do cams and in the process pushrods, inner cam bearings, so I'm not totally clueless, but I'm still a noob. How tricky is it to do basic maintenance on a Boxster? Spark plug changes, oil changes, air filter, fuel filter, whatever maintenance items I might be missing.

At 3k miles/yr, is it likely I'd experience much in terms of mechanical breakdown over the next 2 years (when I'm finally out of college and I'll have a real job)

posts.com: I'm pretty sure there's a guy named Craig who has a list you can put this thing on.

Yeah that's the plan unless I can find a struggling dealership that'll give me over market on my car as a trade in

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26182676
>I know initially the IMS bearing had an 8% failure rate and went through a good number of revisions before Porsche changed the design to eliminate it, how much better are the ones after 2000 that still had IMS bearings?
Not quite correct, the very early ones had ~1% failure rates while around 2002 or so they switched to a weaker, ~10% failure rate part, and around the introduction of the 997/987 they switched again to a different ~1% failure rate part. There are various upgrade kits out there, from simple higher-spec roller bearings to oil-fed sleeve bearings that will 100% certain never ever fail within the lifetime of the engine.
General maintenance is not too bad, although you'll ideally want a lift because lol mid-engined car. Parts are on the pricier side, and the engines take a lot of oil, but on the other hand that means longer oil change intervals.
