posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180574
I don't know if you're much of an EE guy, but the combination of an inductor (coil) and a capacitor (condenser) is one of the basic circuit used to build an oscillator. The electrical energy bounces back from one to the other, continuing to gain strength until it finally discharges - in this case, through the gap of the spark plug. Just running a voltage through a coil and then disconnecting will technically build a substantial transient voltage, but it'll be short and weak compared to how much energy builds up in a resonant circuit, and how long the spark will last since it takes a short but important amount of time for it to loose all of its resonance by continuing to pulse the spark plug.

But yeah try a new module if it's not expensive. Sometimes they just develop short circuits or bad connections that prevent them from accumulating or dissipating energy efficiently.

If an '89 uses a distributor, then another easy thing to try is to get a whole new distributor from a junk yard (not just the cap). Depending on design, there may an obscure little thing in the in the rotor mechanism called a reluctor that works like a little electromagnet like on many things like ABS or crankshaft position sensors, and a combination of heat and age can cause them to work intermittently or not at all. If this is the case, then it's an easy thing to double-check if a new coil doesn't do anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180596
yeah i have no electronics engineering experience at all.

capacitor is cheap enough, ill check distributor tomorrow, should i test the contacts for resistance? voltage?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180608
For something in the distributor itself? Off the top of my head I wouldn't know what exactly to look for even if I had an oscilloscope. That's why the easy thing to do is to just swap in a whole new one and see if that makes the difference. If it doesn't, then that's probably not your problem.

Similarly, basically the easiest way to check the coil is to see if it sparks a plug, and try changing the plug wire if not. You're probably not going to see much of a voltage spike on a
multimeter unless it pops the fuse because it's so brief. There again you'd need an o-scope to see if its actually resonating or just being limp-dicked one shot wonder. I guess a service manual might give you some things to try to measure, but a whole new module is such an easier thing to try because it could be the coil itself that's fucked, and that might not show up on a simple resistance check if it only fails at high voltage or something.

This is key.
The Prius is great, but with their engines shutting off and back on constantly.
Oil needs to be changed, coolant needs to be flushed in all THREE systems.

Unline Honda IMA, the Prius can not work with an old or dead battery.
Oh, and they like to burn oil.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26180420
Don't listen to some of the spergos here saying nothing will apply skill wise. The basics you learned from having ridden a bike do apply to motorcycles. Mountain biking might help a bit if you wanted to get into trials bikes, but street bike wise the only things that will apply will be less from mountain biking more from just bicycles in general, Like the fundamental speed = stability and how to relatively balance on two wheels. Outside of that, that's pretty much it. A lot of motorcyclists may try and gatekeep by saying they have nothing in common, but having watched a lot of people learn to ride, those that knew how to ride bicycles ALWAYS progress much faster than those who have never. Those who never learned to ride a bicycle struggle a LOT to pass basic motorcycle courses in their usually very tight time frame.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180420
alot, depending on how you ride. I dont think any of the other ppl responding have actually mountain biked alot so I think they are coming from the prespective of casual bikers.

If you can clear blacks and blues or jump alot of the flow is exactly the same (dont use arms just turn body look where you want to go etc etc) basically identical when you get above 10 mph.

Low speed manuevers on a motorcycle are going to be much much harder (unless you have good enough balance to trackstand)

But yeah if you are an avid mtb you will probably pass msf first try if you can get the low speed motorcycle stuff down fast. Most of the high speed stuff is the same though regarding targeting and shifting body weight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180502
Depends. Most of the times its a mix of the two.
lower speed, bad road, lean self not bike to keep bike upright.
High speed, solid corner, lean self more than bike for better cornering traction.
Low speed good surface lean bike more than self for more maneuverability.
Emergency avoidance, move bike keep self upright for fastest change of direction in a snap.
Normal riding? Most of the time only the bike has to lean. counter leaning gives you a better view of the road and potential hazards ahead as well as the ability to make those quick snap changes in direction if you need to avoid something in an emergency. There really is no one rule for when and how to lean on a bike. It depends. Unless you're taking corners at three times the posted speed limit, THEN LEAN OFF THE FUCKING BIKE SO YOU STOP LOW SIDING EVERY 6 MONTHS

Lather it in petroleum jelly. I'm restoring my '68 Chrysler Newport right now and some of the rubber bits are hard to find. I lubed them up in petroleum jelly a few times, rubber took it right in and was flexible again like new. So long as it has not cracked, you should be golden.

I'm sure the other anon's armorall technique works too, but with using petroleum jelly, you are literally giving it back what it has lost. Armorall is not the same as what the rubber has lost to make it dry.

Since what they're for is a secret (fucking zoomers really need to ALWAYS specify parts, who taught you people to communicate?) it's hard to help but if you measure all the boot characteristics ID, OD, flange bolt distances etc it's often practical to match them to something else. Someone on an online group for your secret make and model will have solved the problem since there are only so many possible carb boot sizes and carbs. Also when engaging groups and fora post clear pics of your existing boot from front, rear and side.

Examples showing how to describe boots.

>>26180675
Carb boots are a bit different because restoring their outside appearance doesn't penetrate to restore their strength internally.

Boot specialists exist tho and these guys also sell CV disphraghms:

http://jbmindustries.com/index.html

One method which was a one shot deal was soak hardened boots in methylene chloride carb dip for several hours then quickly install boots and carbs before they re-hardened but it doesn't permanently restore suppleness. Best to solve the boot problem (and if keeping bike, get spares).

Trim and window rubber being thinner works far better when treated with goo du jour because it's thinner and flexible.

Carb boots are indeed made of stiffer stuff and once they harden/outgas they're done. There not being very many oddball carb boots playing matchup shouldn't be heinous.

If there is ever a really odd part you have to have, urethane suppliers like Hapco (nice to deal with) sell castable urethanes of various durometers. You could make a silicone mold of an old rubber part to pour a new one. I learned about them making some custom bumper pads for F-16 landing gear maintenance.

Dunno if there's anything on your Chrysler you'd need to make but here's the info. I also work on old cars and trucks but only collect motorbikes.

https://hapcoincorporated.com/materials/brands/hapflex/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180420
Good god, the responses to this are fucking awful.

I rode a mountain bike a lot as a kid (wanted a dirt bike and never got one, so I did the next best thing) and took my MSF on a dual sport and everything immediately felt familiar. Obviously you have to get used to the extra weight and the concept of keeping steady wrist position with your right hand when turning, etc., but beyond that for all beginner low speed stuff it's just a heavy motorized bicycle. Once you go faster around 20-30 mph then you will need to be more conscious of counter steering (literally turn the bars the opposite of where you want to lean, turn the bars to the right slightly to lean left, etc). It's the same on a bicycle, but few people go fast enough to really get a feel for it. Just remember to play with turning the bars the first few times you go faster on a motorcycle and it will make sense immediately. Make sure to also study the physics of riding from Mike on Bikes and Yamaha Champion School so you don't do dumb things out of fear or misinformation like only using the rear brake or thinking you can't brake during a turn, etc. I'd estimate probably 95% of motorcycle riders actually do not use proper techniques because they literally don't understand the physics of it and their lack of knowledge won't show until an emergency situation comes up and they "hadda layer down" because they don't know shit about handling.

>motorcycles steer, lean and brake differently from bicycles

Literally 100% false. They both use conventional steer at low speeds and counter-steering at higher speeds (though most people don't bike fast enough for the crossover to happen). Motorcycle brakes are literally just more powerful bicycle brakes, not even sure where you're getting that would be different.

>>26182286
>You are probably not 6'0+ tall
I'm 6'1", but please give other irrelevant excuses.

>its bending forward (lower back pain) or strain on the wrists if you aren't riding tucked.
Then put lowering links on the rear like I did and put it on the lowest height setting (as long as suspension won't bottom out). Shifts the weight back on your butt and off your wrists, lowers your head out of the wind so you don't get slapped around, increases rake slightly for less darty handling, increases traction and reduces wheelie like MotoGP holeshot device off the line, and still has plenty of cornering clearance for anything short of race pace on track and tracks with much more stability through turns. The first thing everyone should do on any street-ridden supersport motorcycle is lower the rear and leave the front alone, infinitely better street bike that way in literally every capacity. As a bonus, if you're a manlet you don't have to tip toe around and look like a little kid riding his dad's bike. I honestly don't know where the stubbornness to leave the suspension at stock height came from, it's moronic if you aren't constantly jumping side to side or tucking down a straight on a race track.

EJ25s need a timing belt change at around 100k miles, which isn't cheap. Basic parts alone are around $700. If you take the opportunity to change all the idlers, tensioner and water pump (you should), it can easily be $1.5k+ including labor. posts.name: Anonymous

Yeah if you don't know how to do your own work then have a shop check it out and include upcoming recommended service (bring whatever documentation in case something major has already been done or is overdue, and so they generally know what to look for.)

It doesn't sound like a terrible idea, but after 10yr and 100k it'd be a good idea to weed out a possible basket case. If it's in good condition, you might be looking at more like another 5yrs / 50k miles before annoying things show up. It really depends on what condition it is now.

>EJ25s need a timing belt change at around 100k miles, which isn't cheap. Basic parts alone are around $700.
Wrong. Were ever you took your car to scammed you. The process should cost under $1000. But yes, it will need to be done.
Op, take it for a test drive and get the car HOT, cool it off, and get it HOT again. If at any time the temp gauge comes on it needs heads. If it's real bad, the second you get on the interstate the car will overheat. That is the REAL expensive job. It would also be a good idea to take a look at the coolant when the engine is cool. If it's got gunk floating around in it, the gaskets are probably shot. So basically tell the dealer it is gonna need at least $1000. If he says its not the expensive, have his service department quote you. You could also say the heads are probably shot after inspecting the coolant, but I doubt he will give a fuck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26177198
Actual 4th gen lesbianmobile owner here. On the owner forums I see a lot of people having problems with the 2.5's CVT, so make sure you are comfortable with needing to replace the whole thing if the need arises. If you can wait for a 3.6 to come along, do it because that engine + trans combo is just about indestructible. The other thing to look for that most people won't tell you is the 4-way brake connector, which is behind a little plastic door near the rear right jack point. If that thing rusts out the brake lines they all need to be replaced which is expensive and difficult to do correctly yourself. Rear wheel bearings will probably need replacement soon if they haven't been done yet so watch out for that. Check for oil leaks as well but 2012 is probably fine, it was the 2013 2.5s that mainly had problems with that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26172339
Varies.
KO2s come in multiple formulations, your specific size of tire, vehicle weight, weight distribution, choice of wheels, and balance ALL affect tire noise!

Basically, you don't know until you know, and the same tires can surprise you from one vehicle to the next.

KO2s have a reputation for highway noise, but noise quality matters too.
When I had 'em on my 97 K1500, they were plenty noisy on the highway, but far less annoying than Discoverer AT3s on the same truck.
Similar noise level, but less obnoxious sound.

My boss has a newer Yukon on Michelin LTX, and I was impressed at how quiet they are.
On my K1500, fucking obnoxious between 45 and 55, so they're infuriating around town but silent on the highway.

Don't be afraid to bite the bullet and try some shit!
The big generics like Discount Tire won't hesitate to let you return tires if you find 'em obnoxious.
They may not be shit-hot on giving you your money back, but they won't complain one bit if you want to try a different tire.
That's exactly what I did with those Michelins (at a Ford dealer of all things, they had good prices), went back to a set of ATPs that will do just fine for now.

since this is american truck general:

how reliable are gmt900s?

i got scared off from them after watching a few videos about owning them at the 120k+ mile mark where they all seem to fall apart in a expensive manner. usually oil leaks everywhere (rear main seal being the big one), chrome wheels have to get refinished due to being unable to seal air on denalis/escalades, and at least one transmission job. and this if it isn't a dod/afm truck (07-09). the newer trucks need top ends apparently (lifters or cam) if it didn't have oil changes every 3k

is the 6l80e a good transmission? better than the 4l60e? it seems like they're just as willing to blow up desu

does anyone have any experience with the 5.4 3v ford trucks? the 09-14 expeditions/navigators seem more reliable other than the timing chain/oil pump issues on those trucks, which seem just as hit or miss as getting a reliable gm v8. either it craps itself past 120k miles and gets noisy at startup or it's quiet like new to 200k+ miles.

im also not hearing too many transmission issues w/the fords compared to the gm trucks of the same era + the interiors and rest of truck seem sturdier its just that the timing chains are a big job when they need to get done

i like either truck cause i want something that can tow, can take flex fuel (i have 400whp evo on e85 i'll be taking to the track and it would be nice to dump the fuel jugs i dont use into the daily), and i want something comfortable and reliable for $10k~.

the ford trucks are easy to find for the $6-10k mark even a '13-'14 navigator is close to $10k, the gms a little harder but definitely possible for a 07-09 escalade

other option is me just upping my budget for a flex fuel 2011-16 sequoia or armada

>>26181437
It's Crosstrek hate.
Subaru ads used to have blurbs like:
"A four-wheeled defibrillator"
"A 205-horsepower pledge pin"
"Winter is a terrible thing to waste"
"Now they can release Gran Turismo 4"

Crosstrek ads:
"Love"
"Love is out there, find it in a Crosstrek."
"The world keeps getting smaller, leave a small footprint."
"Built to get dirty, not be dirty."

Note the difference. The Crosstrek is a "good car" and it's good for Subaru.
The Crosstrek is, on paper, an amazingly good value and one of the most "practical" and "proper" vehicles Subaru has ever made.
Subaru, compared to their competition, is a tiny company that makes weird vehicles.
Combine that with their rally heritage and the focus on "cars people want," you get quite a brand image, especially for enthusiasts.
The Crosstrek is very much not a "car that people want," the Crosstrek is practical.

From a design history standpoint, it is the most practical and least interesting Subaru ever.
A Subaru you can recommend to Grandma without any second thoughts.
It's comfortable, well made, and competes well with other similar vehicles.

So, it's not very Subish.
It has no heritage, no rally background.
You get the FB20 or FB25, and you can have it in a hybrid version, but that means there's no turbocharged option.
You choose between Manual and CVT, no DCT, not even a conventional automatic option.
It's got all the soul, passion, and enthusiasm of a Corolla Cross sitting on 27" all-seasons.

It's a good car, it's just not much of a Subaru.

Would you rather hobble out of a Dodge Caravan with side-skirts that says "BRAUNABILITY ACCESSIBLE VEHICLE PLATFORM" on it, or something a bit more typical?
No cripple wants the minivan, full stop.
There's a huge business around making vehicles more accessible, and a huge part of that is converting/modifying more interesting, desirable, and entertaining options.

You don't notice the wheelchair bound folks driving around nearly as much anymore.
At one time, it was very noticeable, because you either had the modified "high access" minivans that everyone hated, or you had a small pickup with a lift arm in the back, and that was pretty much it for "accessibility options."
Nowadays, forget about it, they do everything, and in varying degrees of conspicuousness.
It's hard to spot most conversions now, and a huge variety of vehicles are used.

>>26182307
In the USA, if you're a cripple, your insurance might help a little if you buy an approved accessibility package through an approved provider and it's installed in a brand-new vehicle that meets their requirements.

Plenty of cripples here are forced to buy brand-new Kia Rios because it's the only NEW vehicle they can afford.
A cripple in the US pays $250-$350/mo to insure a new Kia Rio, plus the payment on the car, and the payment for the accessibility mods that were done.
So the health insurance "helps" you by forcing you into the cheapest car you can find, the auto insurer hits you with a payment that meets or exceeds what you're paying for the car loan, then you have another payment on top to pay for the insanely overpriced accessibility equipment.

Closest thing to that Seat in the US would be an Audi A3 or a Golf.
If the "average" cripple in the US wants a new Golf, they'll be looking at over $1800/mo for the privilege.
Who the fuck is going to pay $100,000 to drive a Golf for 5 years?
So instead they end up paying $36,000 to drive a Kia Rio for 5 years.

Vomit, etc.

>>26165418
It was so common in the early-mid '00s that you could rice a whole car out with one trip to Pep Boys. They had aluminum GT wings (usually comically undersized), knockoff Sparco seats, underglow, fake vents and scoops, hideous shift knobs, steering wheels, and clamp-on pedals, and various bodyside graphics sold rolled up, and if you had one of the really popular ricing platforms like an EG Civic or DC Integra you could even get application-specific stuff like lowering springs, clear taillights, and I think even bodykits at some locations. (Mine had a few on display but I'm not sure if you could actually buy them off the shelf or if it was just showing that you could special order them.)
Virtually everything was from this "APC" brand that's apparently been dead since '09, hard to even find pics of their shit anymore (and I wish I could come up with one of the ricer aisle at Pep's because it was hilarious) but this one will probably bring back some memories among my fellow 3x year old boomers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26165418
Yep, was definitely a thing. My dad took me to Sydney Show and Shine in 2004 and man it was wild. Everything was chrome and the place smelled like kebabs. I remember dad pointing out that most turbo kits fabbed on these cars didn't even run vacuum lines or oil/water feed - it was bolted on the day and all for show. If your first car was in the style of pic related in those days then you were king shit. I remember seeing chromed out Lancers, Civics, Skylines and Silvias everywhere with flame stickers and sound systems heavier than the car and being so jealous of how cool they were. This was also when you could pick up an R33 Skyline in turbo manual for less than $4k. It was a simpler time indeed.

>>26165418
I was a teenager and into import cars in the 90's. You know how in movies most of the important characters are attractive? Good-looking people exist in real life too, but you're unlikely to find such a concentration of beautiful people in real life as you do in Hollywood movies. It's kind of like that with the cars in those movies. Yes, you could see cars on the street like the ones in the movies, but it would be unusual to see so many that take it quite so far as the ones in the movies. For what it's worth, I consider that style to be more of a 90's thing than an early 00's thing, by the way. By the early 00's, it was already on the way out, and the dotcom crash / small recession around 2002 killed it in the US, imo. For a positive portrayal of that scene, visit your local library and see if they have old copies of Sports Compact Car magazine from the late 90's. For a more mainstream view, check out Bryan's Rice-boy Page. Note that the last update was about six months before "The Fast and the Furious" came out. It's still up at http://www.riceboypage.com/index.html

>>26180905
Not that anon, but I grew up in LA and was in the drift and touge scene quite early, and I'd peg '03 as the year it really took off. People in the Japanese car scene already knew about Initial D, option videos, Drift Bible, etc. at that point and there were some local grassroots drift events at places like "The Balcony" at Willow Springs but '03 is when it took off as a spectator sport with the Dorifuto Showoff and the first D1 exhibition event at Irwindale as well as the first FD round on the other side of the country, and I remember the "what is 'Drifting' and why is it the next big thing?" sorts of articles appearing in mainstream automotive publications after that. I always laugh looking back because I remember one article predicting that trucks were going to become the meta vehicles for it and that drifting events would evolve to include jumps and stuff, of course I don't think anybody back then could've predicted that it'd end up dominated by shit like E46s with NASCAR crate motors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180905
Dude, drifting was invented in the mountains of Japan in the 80's:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=di_X8IQLlAw

This video is from 1987 of Keiichi Tsuchiya as he was just getting mainstream popularity in Japan. It came out of the propensity for a RWD to slide when pushed hard through a corner, which was then exaggerated to own the other competitor, like a motorcycle rider riding a wheelie down a straight because he's so far ahead he doesn't need maximum acceleration. It became its own style/art afterwards. That said, it was not widely known outside of Japan due to the lack of modern internet and a huge language barrier. People likely knew of it, but not most. It started getting TV coverage around the time the first FnF movie came out and all of the games reflected it afterwards.

Yes, rally and other racing forms did it as a byproduct of hard cornering techniques, but no one tried to sustain it as long as possible until the Japanese mountain racers started doing it in the late 80's, likely because that was the first time car suspensions were good enough to actually pull it off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180968
No shit, see:>>26180975

Even Mario Kart had drifting mechanics, but think for one second what country made it. Lots of Japanese-made racing games (and some others that copied them) had drifting discreetly in them, but it was more of a byproduct of driving fast than an end of itself. Americans just took it as the fishtailing they had seen on TV for decades (i.e. Bullitt, Dukes of Hazard, et al) and didn't really think much about it. Drifting was around for a long time before it became visible in America, but that happened in the very early 00's.

posts.name: Anonymous

true, Ridge Racer came out in 1993 and drifting is the key cornering mechanic
Daytona USA in 1994, again making use of relatively realistic drifting. Virtua Racing from '91 didn't have drifting until its 32x release, but might be one of the first games where you could oversteer your way into a spin. Mario Kart may have had push-button drifting but F-Zero nailed that loose and nearly-out-of-control feeling and served as the inspiration for Daytona and RR.

>>26178333
Finland oldie here,
We used to do laps and point to point races(time trials).
This was before common cellphones, gps and so on. We did point to point or laps,one at a time ,because if you got caught, you were "just" speeding, not racing. Guys had CB-radios to do timing(when point to point) and since people knew each other, cheating on timing wasn´t a thing really. No surprise, most runs were at night for less to no trafic, bystanders and cops.
One fun thing was to find out were rally folks had special stages and drive them. Not on the race weekends, of course. Another fun thing was radio-orienteering(dunno what to call it in english). The target car puts the transmitter on and continues to be the stationary target. Others triangulate the signal position by driving around and the team that finds the target with least driven kilometers wins(or finds first) that round.

In the late 70s, virtually all car companies were experimenting with crumple zones and working toward better crash safety.
They knew that actual laws and regulations were likely to follow as independent groups had begun testing and rating the crash safety of popular cars.
>Insert 3 paragraphs about Ralph Nader
The 80s were safety beta testing for the world.
Germans, forget about it, Mercedes W126 platform was called "the safest car in the world" repeatedly over its lifespan, the Germans did not struggle to understand and improve safety.

American cars, when they were still huge and overbuilt, excelled in early safety tests with only minor additions like proper crumple zones, and improvements to seats, headrests, and seatbelts.
As the malaise era progressed, they were forced to make their cars more economical, often at the sacrifice of safety.

Japan started at a disadvantage, their cars were small, light, and economical, it's what was helping them gain traction in the US in the 1970s.
Every quick-and-dirty solution to safety that had yet been tried was based around size, scale, weight.
>Need some more safety? Make it a foot longer, sure it adds 250lbs but it adds 12 more inches of air between the driver and the crash!
It was incompatible with main selling point of Japanese cars during the malaise period.

The simultaneous push for safety and economy can be seen easily through the cars on offer in the US during the 80s and 90s.
Carburetors died, cars got smaller, aerodynamics took a front seat in the design process, and laws and regulations related to vehicle safety started being implemented while emissions laws were being expanded.
The late 80s and early 90s show automakers struggle to adapt from a world with almost no regulations on automotive manufacturing (Pre 1973), to a heavily regulated modern automotive market defined by safety and emissions concerns.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26179905
(cont.)
Manufacturers struggled to keep pace, and it shows.
As they started to catch up and engineer their way around these issues in more effective and more efficient ways, cars started objectively improving.
The last decade is clear evidence that they've managed to surpass some of these issues, and get ahead of them in such a way that it grants them more freedom in what they can produce.

1969 Mustang with the Boss 429 V8, 375HP/450lbft
1980 Mustang with the 255 V8, the only V8 on offer in 80 and 81, 119HP/194lbft
1996 Mustang Cobra 5.0-based V8, 305HP/317lbft
The current Mustang Shelby GT500 5.2L V8 produces 760HP/625lbft

Power output is hardly the tell-all of automotive design, but it does paint a picture.
The Mustang is a great example, it's a pony car, it exists to look good and go fast and make the brand look better as a whole.
It's equal parts product and advertisement, excess is a requirement, pantomime is essential.
When you see the power that was available in the Mustang in a given era, you're seeing the power Ford was able to make, you're seeing the limit they ran into.
That limit might've been set by emissions laws, safety concerns, time constraints, economic conditions, fuel consumption, parts availability, internal issues with labor or failures in management.
Whatever the cause behind it, it demonstrates that there were limitations, that the product was being held back.
As they overcome these issues, it shows in the improvements they're able to offer, it conveys that they were overcoming the limitations that held them back previously.

Modern cars are objectively better, you only have to go back one decade at a time to see the evidence.
Obviously that doesn't account for style and appearance, I'm talking about numbers.
Power, economy, safety, what can be quantified on paper, every time you look it's better than it was before.

posts.com:
>>26180109
>Not in ease of serviceability
Totally agree.
>or how long they last.
Totally wrong.
You can't remotely compare the lifespan of a modern vehicle to its counterpart in the 70s or 80s.
Over the last 50 years, we've steadily increased the typical lifespan of major components of vehicles across the board.

In the 70s, a common tire typically lasted around 20k miles in an appropriate application.
Now, even the cheapest tires have warranties in excess of 40k miles, some on excess of 80k.

The majority of manufacturers in the 70s recommended 2500-3500 mile oil changes.
Now, 5000 is typical, with some in excess of 10,000 miles between oil changes.

In the 60s, 70s, and 80s, warranties varied as manufacturers weighed the costs and benefits of offering and honoring them.
1-year 12,000 miles was typical, but many went as high as 5-year 50,000 miles when they could afford it.
Now, numerous manufacturers offer powertrain warranties in excess of 10 years and 100,000 miles.

Manufacturers didn't expect their own vehicles to reach 100,000 miles back in the 60s and 70s.
It was expected to need major service before then, and average consumers were quickly priced out of repairing the vehicle.
It is generally agreed that vehicles in the 60s and 70s had a lifespan of "up to" about 100,000 miles.
By the late 1990s, many (certainly not all) new vehicles being produced could be expected to last in excess of 200,000 miles.
Now, many (again, definitely not all) vehicles produced can be reasonably expected to last in excess of 300,00 miles.

The average age of a registered vehicle on the road in the United States has doubled since 1970, from a mere 5.6 years to in excess of 12.

Cars are more reliable, require less service, and last longer.
>Modern cars are objectively better, you only have to go back one decade at a time to see the evidence.
>Obviously that doesn't account for style and appearance, I'm talking about numbers.

>>26180874
That'd be the A604 41TE.
It was the first of Chrysler's Ultradrive transmission, which is still in production to this day in 4 and 6 speed variants.
The Ultradrive trannies are early examples of electronically controlled automatics.
They were very similar to but distinct from the earlier TorqueFlite transmissions they replaced.
They were notoriously unreliable pieces of shit in the early days.
Stupid mistakes, like putting Dexron labels on the dipstick and in the manual when Dexron fluid murders it and it actually requires ATF+3/+4.

The 42RLE, 40TES, 41TES, and 62TE are the more modern versions you'll find in numerous 2003 and later Chrysler vehicles.
They're perfectly good trannies that compete well with offerings from Chevrolet and Ford.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26180874
Oh and they weren't exaggerating, which is kind of fun.
That Jag they're poking fun at is the XJ6.
You had the choice between two AJ6 inline-6 engines, the 2.9L 165 horsepower (175 lb ft torque) or the 3.6L 220 horsepower (240 lb ft).
Both came attached to a pathetic ZF 4HP22.

Chrysler was right to brag when comparing their brand new 41TE to the decade old Friedrichshafen 4HP22.
It was a simpler transmission, merely an improved and strengthened variant of the 3HP that had been around since 1972.
In the format offered in the Jag, it could handle a paltry 280 lb ft of torque, falling short of the 300 lb ft rating of the weakest, shittiest version of the Ultradrive, the 41TE.
Later variants of the Ultradrive 4-speed will happily hold back 400 lb ft of torque in their stock form.

That ad is from 1988, but the W126 was produced until 1991, so really it was Mercedes playing catch-up.

The W126 didn't get an airbag until 1980, didn't get self-leveling suspension until 1979, and the 4G-Tronic transmission was very old-fashioned despite its extreme reliability and lifespan.

To compete with Chrysler, Mercedes had to use a time machine in order to introduce the same features several years and in some cases decades before the competition, and it was only their strive to beat out the masterful Chrysler Imperial that led the recursive time-loop development of the W126.
So sure, the W126 platform includes some of the greatest cars that have ever and will ever be made, but it's only because Chrysler and time-travel, don't you forget it faggots.
